article.title: Spatially resolved multiomics on the neuronal effects induced by spaceflight in mice
article.abstract: Impairment of the central nervous system (CNS) poses a significant health risk for astronauts during long-duration space missions.

sections.introduction: In preparation for long-duration lunar and Mars missions, it is crucial to investigate the health risks to astronauts that are posed by exposure to the space environment1.
sections.methods: A cohort of 12-week-old female BALB/c mice were flown to the ISS and housed in the Rodent Habitat for 39–42 days.
sections.results: To identify specific cellular microenvironments affected by spaceflight, we combined the techniques of spatial transcriptomics (ST; 10X Genomics Visium) and single-nucleus multiomics (snMultiomics; gene expression and chromatin accessibility; 10× Genomics Single Cell Multiome ATAC + Gene Expression) on mouse brain.
sections.discussion: In this study, we used brain samples from ground control and spaceflown female mice from the RR-3 mission to understand the effects of the space environment at high resolution: at the level of individual brain cell types and brain regions.

technologies: 10× genomics single cell multiome atac + gene expression

technologies_detail.text: 10× Genomics Single Cell Multiome ATAC + Gene Expression
technologies_detail.normalized: 10× genomics single cell multiome atac + gene expression

article.insights_summary: This study demonstrates the effects of spaceflight on the central nervous system (CNS) at high resolution, revealing significant alterations in essential brain processes, including neurogenesis, synaptogenesis, and synaptic transmission.
article.acknowledgments: We would like to gratefully acknowledge the assistance of San-huei Lai Polo with hosting data on the NASA GeneLab server.
